Name: Maneesh2700
Title: Good for Art Lovers
Review: The is undoubtedly a place where all art lovers should go. Especially we should our kids there to make them aware of our art heritage. Though I wish the collection was a bit more vast

Name: Madhulika L
Title: Superb display of modern Indian art
Review: At only Rs 20 per Indian adult (children up to 18 years of age can visit free) and Rs 300 per foreigner, this museum is a must-visit if you’re keen on modern art. The museum premises spread over several buildings that are part of Jaipur House, a palace initially built for the Maharaja of Jaipur, back in 1936. Some of the subsidiary buildings house administrative offices and so on, but the art is mainly in the New Wing, inaugurated in 2009. Here, you can see an excellent, chronologically arranged, of modern Indian art, beginning around the period that saw ‘Company Art’: from there, right up to the present day, there are dozens of stunning artworks, with some scattered sculptures here and there. Many of the greats are here: Amrita Sher-Gil, Abanindranath Tagore, Nandlal Bose, Jamini Roy, KK Hebbar, MF Husain, Satish Gujral… and many more. There are several almost iconic paintings in the collection, which spreads over three floors (staircases connect the floors, as do wheelchair-friendly ramps; there are also elevators between the floors). Note that photography without a flash is allowed, as long as you aren’t taking photos of yourself or of other people. To understand the displays better, you can also opt for one of the guided tours, starting every hour or so, that are conducted. These are bi-lingual, English and Hindi, and are done for groups: if you have paid for the tour, you simply join the group starting next. Do remember to go out into the grounds of the museum and check out some of the sculptures on the lawns. There’s an especially striking metal tree (with utensils as the ‘leaves’) by Subodh Gupta which is truly memorable.

Name: AirborneSpoon
Title: Very Dissatisfied
Review: When I'm reviewing places in India I try not to compare them to similar places in the West because it's not fair due to the differences in their operating budgets. But inorder to give the Western readers of this post an honest review and a starting reference the two must be compared.  On to the Modern Art Museum. This museum had many examples of Modern Indian art stretching back a hundred or so years. The art was colorful, unique and came in many different mediums. I found the art very interesting and in some cases very similar to Western Art, Cubism came to mind.  The interior of the museum was very poorly layed out with no flow or any particular reason that I could figure out. Unfortunately, like most other museum's in India this one was in need of a total make over. The paint was chipping off, the carpets and walls were dirty and the paintings at time appeared to be hung by simple hooks that Americans would by at Home Depot or Lowe's hardware stores. To top it off but I expected this, no snack bar and the gift shop was horrible. Are there no quality gift shops in any Indian tourist site? I just want to buy a guide book, post card and magnet.

Name: Rush401
Title: Modern art
Review: Not so great experience! Only one building with art and few sculptures..the rest is all shut..considering we have a so many artists through the centuries. Atleast make a attempt to show and display more works..

Name: Let's Go Sightseeing
Title: Day well spent!
Review: I spent a winter afternoon strolling through the galleries at NGMA. There are a number of galleries with varied exhibitions. The permanent gallery features paintings by Raja Ravi Verma, Rabindranath Tagore, Amrita Sher Gil etc. Each piece of art is a visual delight while a few give points to ponder.Two temporary exhibits that stand out in my mind are Satyajit Ray & Upendra Maharathi. I didn't know much about the late Mr. Ray; so it was an education for me. & the late Mr. Maharathi's works are stunning!NGMA has a parking outside & is huge; so wear comfortable shoes & be ready to walk a lot.

Name: Steve Falqowski
Title: I thought they have more interesting works
Review: This is the biggest art gallery in India. Staff was very helpfull, but art shop has just a little thing to sell. All pictures look the same. It was ok, but nothing special.

Name: Nadia I
Title: Wonderful visit
Review: It was raining on one of the days in Delhi, we decided its a good day for a museum.The wing that was open, had many beautiful pieces made by using different styles. There are guided tours , which we did not know about. First one at 11 am.Next we visited Maharithi Exhibit in Jaipur house, that was out standing. Glad it was raining that day, because we would have missed it.There is a ticket for 600 Rupees , that covers both buildings.

Name: Nikki S
Title: Great museum
Review: We had a great visit to this museum. It is a very interesting collection, and I learned a lot about the history of Indian art. There was a lot of construction and getting into.rhe museum was initially confusing, but it was definitely worth a visit. We weren't allowed to bring bags but they did let my son bring his sketchbook and a pencil in (although he really wanted to bring more supplies since he loves sketching art at museums.)

Name: Tarique S
Title: Mecca of the Connoisseur of Art
Review: National Gallery of Modern Art at the time of its inception (1954) was compared to the 'Venice Biennale" by one of the leading newspaper of the country. It has surely come a long way since then. With its colossal collection of Paintings, Sculpture and Photography by some of the finest and renowned artists of India, NGMA is definitely 'The Mecca' for art lovers. Situated at the central Hexagon near India Gate inside the premise of Jaipur House, this museum is a must visit, I would say. The museum has been set up expertly into four floors, each displaying illustrations by different artists of different period. As you walk on each floor, appreciating the oeuvre by different artists, you get educated as how the Indian paintings got evolved from miniature ones to larger than life size paintings. The museum exhibits myriad genre of Indian paintings ranging from Buddhists, Hindu mythology, Mughal, British era, modern day paintings and abstract painting as well.At the time of my visit to this museum, the bottom most gallery displayed the photography by Nimai Ghosh, who captured in his camera, some of the memorable moments from the life of Satyajit Ray (Oscar Award Winning Bollywood Director). The second floor had collection from pre to post independent era. The third and the fourth floor was gracefully exhibited by modern day and abstract paintings. Sculptures have been placed in a very beautiful manner on second and third floor. The entire museum has been set up beautifully in a much uncluttered style and the lights have been used with absolutely perfect tone and intensity.Adjacent to Main Museum building lies the Jaipur House which is used to showcase the work of different artists from time to time. Presently, the Hall is exhibiting the great work of Upendra Maharathi and the exhibition has been named as "Shashwat". Maharathi was a true Gandhinian and had immense faith Buddha. His 112 feet long work of art depicting the life of Gautama Buddha is also on display.Conclusively I could say that this place is not just for the connoisseur of art but for the amateurs too as it is very educative and very enlightening.Important Info:1. The museum is opened From Tuesday to Sunday from 10 am to 5 pm.2. Free Parking is available in front of gate no 3 of Museum3. The entry fee for Indian citizen is INR 20 and that for foreign nationals is INR 500.4. A guided walk is organised every day at 1130 am, 01:30 pm and 3:30 pm. This guided walk is free of cost. The guide helps in understanding the museum and the art in a much better way.5. Photography is allowed inside the museum, but one can use only mobile phone cameras and not the professional cameras. Be sure to switch off the flash of your mobile phones while clicking photos. No selfie is allowed inside the museum. 6. Locker facility is available free of cost inside museum.7. Museum Shop is situated right at the entrance of the museum.

Name: Sunil
Title: Decent museum
Review: This place is nice to watch the art gallery.it has the entrance fee it's quite expensive but it's a good walk through the museum

Name: ghoomboom
Title: Good Gallery of contemporary Modern Indian Art
Review: Situated on the C-Hexagon of India Gate near Shershah Road, this gallery is a great collection of works of modern Indian renowned painters like Raja Ravi Varma, Nand Lal Bose, Amrita Shergill, M F Hussain etc. The Gallery is spread over three floors and many times there are exhibitions also organised here. The campus is big and beautiful and exhibition building is only a part of it. I think it has an Auditorium also. There are many stone sculptures put in the gardens in the campus. Very quite and serene atmosphere. The ticket for Indians is only Rs 20/-. One may visit this gallery if interested in the works of contemporary Indian painters.

Name: Travelling_LindaG
Title: Very good gallery!
Review: Just go if you like old and new art, thought most of the art was amazing! Child friendly, lots too see!

Name: DOMINIQUE L
Title: TO BE AVOIDED / FOREIGHERS HAVE TO PAY A RIDICULOUS ENTRY FARE
Review: I am a French Citizen. I have been to India more than 10 times.I had to pay for visiting this museum a, hefty amount of 500 Rps while Indian citizens just pay 20 Rps : I consider this is very unfair to charge so much firstly for what the museum has to offer, secondly and mainly to make such discrimination for foreign visitors.I know that some other sites in India do the same discrimination against foreign visitors, but this is not a valid reason especially taking into account that the National Gallery of Modern Art is not at all a prime site to visit. I have been in more than 180 countries in the world ; very few countries apply such discrimination fares against foreign visitors; and then they do is in a much smaller ratio. Furthermore, photos are not allowed iInside ; I would consider when paying 500 rps, which by the way is expensive even for european standards, I should have the right to make photos.I felt therefore very very badly welcomed in this museum. Of course, there are many things to see in India ; that is why I went to India many times but I feel very uneasy and not welcomed nicely in this country due to this kind of treatment of foreign visitors.'Incredible India' (the motto of the Tourism office) ; Yes incredible! : 'incredible' is the treatment of foreign visitors !!!!!

Name: JenMSim
Title: Great Experience of Modern Indian Art
Review: My husband and I visited this museum and took a guided tour with the museum's Assistant Curator. I would highly recommend this tour, as the Asst Curator provided a deep level of context and understanding than we would have experienced on our own. The temporary exhibits were very interesting and well curated, especially the current show at the Jaipur House. Highly recommended to visit if you are exploring museums in Delhi.

Name: George C
Title: Discriminatory prices
Review: If places charge tourists outrageous entrance fees compared to locals (500 vs 20 rupees) then deservedly they will lose tourist custom.  They certainly lost mine.

Name: Andrei Dorian G
Title: Works of Modern Indian Painters
Review: If it's to hot outside or raining and u had enough of classical Indian art you can admire in here work of modern Indian painters such as: Amrita Sher-Gil or the Mumbai Progressive Artists Group with very impressive pieces from M. F. Hussain.

Name: Being Dilliwaala
Title: A journey through more than 300 years of Indian art
Review: With free guided tours at 11 am , 1:30 pm & 3:30 pm, NGMA offers a journey unparalleled.  From miniature painting to oil paintings to sketches, it's a time travel opportunity. Take time to notice and asses each art work and experience how the society changed with time.

Name: designER_SACHIN
Title: Visit Place of Art & Modern Art
Review: The National Gallery of Modern Art is the premier art gallery located near India gate comes under Ministry of Culture, Government of India. The motto of gallery is to organize, maintain and develop galleries for permanent display. Its is one the the perfect place for art lovers keen to know the Indian history along with modern art under the same roof.Art gallery is the premier place of its kind in India. The gallery is a presenting the cultural ethos of the country and showcases the changing art forms through the passage of the last hundred and fifty years.

Name: michael s
Title: Foreigners pay 25 X what Indians pay
Review: Title says it all.  Weak collection as well, bad lighting.  Once again racist/nationalistic  pricing and show of importance takes precedence over actual substance.

Name: Katie C
Title: Cash only
Review: We had this as a stop on our tour of Delhi, but were sad to find the ticket office was cash only.  We didn't have enough cash on us to get in, so we were walked around the sculpture gardens to at least have a bit of an experience here.  The galleries looked lovely through the windows, and I'm so sad we weren't able to go in.  I do think this is a good stop, but be sure to bring plenty of cash!

Name: IckFick
Title: Beautiful collection but poorly managed
Review: Being a recently new arrival in Delhi I thought I should become familiar with more sights and museums. The NGMA is not too far from my place so I walked there on a Sunday late morning. It’s a bit confusing as there are several entrances but only Gate 3 is for visitors. Then you must walk towards the back of the property to New Gallery where I had to wait for a ticket salesperson. Once inside there is no map or explanation of the gallery. But there are great collections of interesting ‘modern’ Indian art. One main issue was lighting. Many of the pieces have glass but not the good kind. The cheap kind that reflects the poorly placed lights in every display. This is ironic because they make a point of telling you not to use flash with photos but the lighting is terrible. The collection is pretty amazing tho. After New Gallery I was told to go out and turn left for another exhibition but there was next to no signage and no personnel so I gave up and left. It’s a pity that the managers of the gallery have no interest in properly preserving and displaying such amazing art but only promoting themselves. Invest a bit into this place and it is incredible. Instead there are too many underpaid ‘guards’ and crappy lighting. But still go and see it.

Name: vidushi jain
Title: Delhi visit
Review: This place is a delight to visit as it has various modern arts. This place is amazing for art lovers as it has many sculptures made of bronze and other  materials. So, you can visit this place with friends and family and have fun..

Name: seeker_here
Title: Worth a Visit
Review: Delhi has many museums and galleries but the National Gallery of Modern Art is among the top ones to visit in the city.

Name: Anny454
Title: A brilliant morning!
Review: I was taken here by my guide at the start of two days discovering the arts & crafts of India.  Initially a little reluctant, I quickly saw that this gallery provided an excellent introduction, showing clearly how external cultures impacted on indigenous art.  The modern building on several floors is light and airy.  Some of the lighting is too intrusive, but on the whole pictures are well displayed.  I am now a fan of the work of Jamini Roy.

Name: 240kundang
Title: Paintings Gallery
Review: If you like old paintings. This place is good. A person also gives a guided tour if enough participants are there. 3 floors with different styles of paintings of different era. Some of them are really grand.

Name: Amolak Rattan K
Title: A Treasure of artifacts and paintings
Review: Originally a residence of Royal Family Of JAIPUR State, now it is a beautiful and wonderful place to have a look on some of the artifacts and Paintings. You can spend lot of time to get detailed picture of each of the rare items.Governor Amolak Rattan Kohli

Name: aditi d
Title: Good collection & great tour!
Review: The collection at the NGMA is impressive and has decent information displays. However the highlight of our visit was a guided tour by Arko Ganguly. He is very impressive and it was one of the best art tours I have done across the world. He used the painting as a lens to walk through the history of India. The sculpture gallery is worth a visit too. So do visit first for the tour and then again to soak the art in. Thanks, Arko!

Name: Victor
Title: Excellent collection
Review: Quite a learning experience. Pretty inspirational to be honest. Hopefully they will have the Jaipur house restored soon for the other 17000 paintings in storage right now.

Name: Rubes J
Title: Excellent insight to historical journey
Review: We went here on a Sunday and joined one of the free curated walks lead by assistant curator Mr Ganguli. He passion is infectious and one would not have gained as much but just walking around. The tour was almost 2 hours but it went very quickly and covered all floors. We were really able to see India’s journey through the history of art. Definitely recommend if you like art and sculpture.

Name: ndocking
Title: Wonderful. Excellent value for 500 rupees
Review: One of the best modern art galleries I have been to . The most engaging and knowledgable assistant curator and the free guided tours are a must. You leave having an understanding  of Indian history and culture through the eyes of Indian artists. Brilliant few hours here

Name: 2torontotraveller
Title: Art from 1850s to Now
Review: This is truly an Art Museum.  It has a building that houses paintings from 1850s  to present time.  The building is very well laid out as it has 3 floors with the main floor starting at colonial times and the top floor ending at current times. Unlike a lot of Modern Art museums that hold large abstract paintings, the majority of the paintings are relatively small and would fit into your living room.  The basement of this building holds special exhibits.There is a building beside the main building that holds scruptures.  Most of these are very nice.  Since the exhibitions are well laid out I could get sense of how art developed in India.  I would recommend going to this museum.It costs 500 RS to go to this museum if you are a foreigner and you need to pay it in cash.

Name: The Rissala
Title: SUPER TIME!!!  GREAT COLLECTIONS.
Review: THE STAFF IS GREAT. THE COLLECTION IS WELL PUT TOGETHER AND GREAT.  Great place for Indian art and art lovers to study and watch real art . well put together and a must for all students

Name: RAJENDRA884 PRASAD
Title: Don't go by the name, it also has historic paintings
Review: I visited this place for the first time in my life (58 years old), despite being a born Delhite. Modern art is not just about colours splattered on sheets or walls, it is far beyond and this place has it - paintings, statues, murals, stone craft art, metal craft art etc.It has paintings of renowned painters of India as also statues crafted by brilliant artists.

Name: Marc K
Title: Museum is OK, but the Museum guide makes this place 5 / 5
Review: I had an afternoon to spare in New Delhi so I decided to see what they have to offer in the museum modern art.I'll set the scene very quickly, from the outside the place looks great, as you slowly get closer you realise you're heading into what looks like a college campus. As I arrived (and getting charged 25x price of locals - about £5) I was in. Initially, I didn't have high hopes for the place, until I realised I came at the same time as the guided tour, it's then when my perception of this place changed.The curator of the museum knows his audience, we didn't know the artists, or what on earth the pictures meant. He gave an interesting and relevant history of the art, from early Indian works, through to when western civilisation came and beyond, cleverly linking each piece of random piece of art on what I wouldn't take a second glance at and really making me think about it.We only got through about 3/4 of the ground floor before it was over. Then we were left to explore the rest of the place for ourselves.Like many of the reviews here - visit this place for the curator. He loves that place and after the tour, you'll probably love it too.

Name: Little Wandering Wren
Title: A shambolic delight
Review: Initial Impressions are poor. Opening times have been changed to 11 am, this is not reflected in their publicity. The English tour which is supposed to be at 11 am finally gets going at nearer 12 Noon, and is hijacked by a group of students from a local college of Fine Arts. There is a flood in the shop. The cafe, toilets and general lighting and facilities are disappointing for India's premier modern art space.The special exhibition on Indigenous Australia is wonderful and encourages me to persevere, and at this point out give the staff a special mention especially our enthusiastic tour guide. You get the impression that everyone here is doing their best they just need some investment into what could be an amazing place.We can see renovations are taking place outside in the palace out the front and our guide tells us there are special challenges placing art in historic buildings, the reason the modern art gallery was built.I would strongly recommend all visitors take the tour to understand what the Museum are about, how they define modern art. You will not be disappointed. Alone just wandering in, you might be.

Name: PushExplore
Title: A nice experience
Review: The visit to the National Gallery of Modern Art was quite nice. They have lots of really cool works of art and it was actually better than what I had expected it to be. I had a few hours to spare in between meetings, so this proved to be a good pit stop.

Name: Ashish S
Title: Knowledegable visit
Review: This visit was very knowledgeable for me. Got to know many things during this visit to the National Gallery.

Name: mehtarakeshkumar56
Title: art times
Review: the museum has all sort of art work from the ancient time to the present art form . a must visit to the museum when you in delhi .

Name: Witoldzio
Title: make sure to take the free tour
Review: The actual palace is currently under renovation and the exhibits are located in the modern buildings.We took the free tour and the guide was simply excellent. He took us to several parts of the exhibit and shared with us a very well prepared and simply fascinating commentary about the artworks. Even the least academically prepared would enjoy this visit. We enjoyed it very much. The museum has paintings and sculpture by many of the main representatives of 20th century Indian art and before. I learned about many important artists and their language, Amrita Sher-Gill, Haren Das, Raja Ravi Varma, Bhinod Mukherjee etc.

Name: Amolak Rattan K
Title: A wide collection from 19th century onwards
Review: From the National collection you will find the paintings of renowned Indian artists like Raja RaviVerma, Amrita Shergill and Jamini Roy and others . The gallery also has retrospective shows of Indian and International Artists . Governor Amolak Rattan Kohli

Name: Chandan P
Title: Very much to see in the museum
Review: A lots of art have been kept here to see the visitors. This is very clean gallery. Many facalities are available like drinking water and washroom.

Name: ganesh79
Title: ”Modern” ?
Review: I was expecting actual MODERN ART but saw paintings mostly from the 1700-1800!? If you want to see actual MODERN art dont go here for that. A few paintings from 2000 but thats about it. Not really worth the 500 rupees for us foreign tourists.

Name: Roopam Shyam
Title: Family's Day Out with Children
Review: What began as a Summer Holiday activity turned out to be a family's day out filled with fun and masti.Located on the India Gate Circle, Best way to reach besides your car is by Metro. Mandi House or Central Secretariat. A Uber/Ola should cost around 60 to 90 Rupees.There is an entry ticket of Rs 20/- for Indians and Rs 500/- for Foreign nationals.The Art gallery spans basement ground and three floors. Fully air conditioned and good arrangement to sit on each floors.The Paintings and artefacts are mesmerising. Many of them are so vivid that they transform you to the British or pre British era.I visited along with my 10 year old son, initially apprehensive that the kind might find it difficult to enjoy the art. But contrary to my expectations he was the one who enjoyed the most.To top it all if you are looking at the leisurely weekend trip you can first proceed to CP for a sumptuous meal before heading here. We had our Lunch at "Kake da Dhaba" Their butter chicken is to die for... and it prepared us for the two to three hours the art gallery takes to be relished properly.

Name: nik_0107
Title: Good collection
Review: A well organized gallery operated by a Government Ministry. A nominal entrance fees, interesting for those who follow modern art.

Name: Picky2traveler
Title: Great art, not always well displayed
Review: I went to see the paintings by Amrita Sher-Gil. They had a dozen or so of her works hung together, but the lighting was poor. One had glass and no matter where I stood, I couldn’t get away from the reflections. A few others had glaring misdirected lights in the way. The building is nice and if you go in summer go early because the AC doesn’t reach to the 3rd and 4th floors where the most modern, and most interesting to me, works are located.

Name: Kat_Dev_Indra
Title: Great collection of art
Review: A place very modern, well curated and representative of  the history of art leading up to the contemporary. Not very crowded but that has to do with the position of art in Indian mind space.That day when we were visiting the entry gate were changed. There was delayed opening but the staff was very helpful and somewhat apologetic.We went on the organised walk, which was worth the wait. Thanks to the museum staff who did the guided walk-in  art style and history was explained wonderfully. Made our visit worth the effort.The collection is wide, so please have comfortable shoes and lots of time on hand. The museum has the unique style of the Indian Government establishment...with the disorganised material, poor maintenance, a very basic kind of cafe/canteen which appears surefire for picking infections at its level of hygiene.The architecture is grand and does justice to a monument housing india's artistic treasures. But then there were packages strewn around or stacked on the walls...enjoy it as India' belief in managing physical things. A different sense of aesthetics.The parking is only for government  or modern high castes of government officials. if you are ' 'private' then no parking...well those are the modern shudras so why bother!That's living art :-)The museum is an attempt to represent Indian Art in a Western museum format...but falls way short of that because of the general way government runs such institutions- do not compare the establishment because it is confused as it serves the modern rulers - Indian government and tries to compete with international museums... The result you would see.Recommend you keep your focus only on the paintings...do not worry about the peripherals or the system.Because the Art collection is marvellous and captures centuries. Definitely visit at least a couple of times.A request to authorities... Government  museums generally have free entry.

Name: PatilChinar
Title: Good Fusion of Modern Art
Review: Simple and Classic are the only 2 words which I'll use to describe this place. If you have a keen interest in art, do visit this place.

Name: 632tvr
Title: A great interlude!
Review: This is well organised and has a lot of modern art work in an easily seeable and enjoyable manner. Take about two hours.

Name: noopur s
Title: amazing piece of modern arts
Review: amazing sculptures and piece of mordern arts can be found here. reasonable entry fee as well, so a must go place

Name: verenmitter
Title: Excellent place
Review: Very well kept museum and very good collection of art. Must visit place if you are in delhi. It is right on India gate C circle. walking distance from India gate.

Name: AnitaNewportBch
Title: Wonderful Indian modern art
Review: We easily spent two hours here, the grounds are lovely and the two main collections we came to see Dhanraj Bhagat and Amrita She Gil did not disappoint.  There were many more artists' work that were unique and thought provoking, and our afternoon was spent happily.  Definitely a worthwhile stop for art lovers.

Name: Animesh
Title: Artistic, Classic, Impressive: 12,000 Sq Mtrs Exhibition Space is one of the World's Largest Art Meusum
Review: Located in the heart of the city (Outer Circle, Hexagonal C of India Gate), this is the place for the art lovers and artists. The complex has a number of buildings housing exhibition halls, administrative offices, cafeteria and the lawns outside having marvellous sculpture. This is ideal to go out, savour the art and sculpture in all its forms and come back as a satisfied soul. One of my favourite places in Delhi but I have complaint with self of not having been able to visit it more than once. It is the premier art gallery under Ministry of Culture. The main museum at Jaipur House was established on 29 Mar, 1954 with branches later at Mumbai & Bangalore. It has a collection of more than 14000 art and sculpture works including by artists such as Thomas Daniell, Raja Ravi Verma, Rabindranath Tagore, Nandalal Bose, Jamini Roy, Amrita Shergil and other foreign artists. With 12,000 square meters of exhibition space, the Delhi branch is one of the world's largest modern art museums.A must visit place for all tourists and Delhites. Highly recommended.

Name: PeterBruceG
Title: 1 to 2 hours
Review: The buildings are central and Easy to move between. Of course we are as far in as the charge a lot more but that’s why we are here to spend our money. It’s a great collection of Indian modern Art a lot of which I had no idea it existed. The colonial. Era is White centric, British. My favourite part was the interactive portion from an Italian artist.

Name: Sophieffc
Title: Very interesting
Review: Fascinating art collection in the heart of New Delhi. Good selection of historical and modern abstract pieces from local artists.

Name: mohitlohani
Title: Access the best of Indian Art
Review: It has India's best collection of Art and is conveniently situated at India Gate circle with ample car parking (Timings: 1100-1800, Mon closed). The New Wing is well lit up and centrally air conditioned and most of the admirable collections are at Ground & First Floor. A Gift Shop offers printouts of iconic paintings.One or two hours get easily immersed peacefully in admiration of the works here.

Name: Shanth148
Title: An outstanding permanent exhibition of Indian Art!
Review: We were most pleasantly surprised to see an amazing array of Indian Art over nearly 200 years...starting from the East India Company- the paintings of Thomas Daniel which have captured the Calcutta of old, and the Hoogly and the surrounding places....really shows us after 200 years what it must have been like in those days.Then the Tagores, Raja Ravi Verma, Amrita SherGill, Jamini Roy, Nandalal Bose and a whole plethora of Indian Artists of that Era; as well as a lot many others by British Artists.Then the Bombay Progressive Artists Group....really lovely, one must have a look.Finally there is a new section of the likes of Panniker, Anjali Ela Menon, Subodh Gupta, Prabhakar Kolte, Biren De, and a whole host of wonderful artists. Felt awed and so happy to see so many illustrious artists up front. Apparently in 2009, Sonia Gandhi had opened this permanent exhibition.A must see for all!

Name: Nigel G
Title: Stunning and Thought Provoking
Review: The entry wing of the building was holding a special exhibition to commemorate the 100th birth anniversary of Dhanraj Bhagat. Some sculptures are impressive but his felt pen efforts to my mind are simple doodlings! I fail to appreciate the art value in the work. Moving on to the main building. What a magnificent collection.  The Head Study by Rabindranath Tagore is said to be a geometric image in the style of Escher. Very impressive. Abstract work by Jyoti Bhatt is colourful and activating . I stood and pondered it for a while. Works by G R Santosh are absolutely captivating . He titles one work ".............." - challenging and powerful for a title. The work embraces in abstract form the female reproductive system in art. Maybe that's just what I see, but clearly the work of a very talented artist. A similar egg abstract work is just as compelling. Ompakesh work 'green to yellow lotus' - again stunning and vivid. Manu Perekha's 'evening in Benares' is impressive and loaded with detail. I love this work and could admire it for a considerable time. There is a whole wall devoted to ink works of F N Souza - his seated woman 1984 is powerful and illustrates the enormous potential in black and white. Landscape of Goa by Nirmal Kapoor is also worth a mention.There are a few old masters related to the colonial era.Pyne's 'Moon Bath' is appealing and colourful, the work draws you too it. IGoing on to sculpture. A definitively thought provoking piece is by Navjot Altaf, 'Palani's Daughters of Pieces - I'm so at a loss without a commentary, but it's rare to see sculptures with fully recessed vagina's, unless it is intended to depict the birth of the pieces resting between the open legs of Palini. Would love to discuss this work with the artist herself. Jankirams 'Christ' is monumental and dominating. Great piece of work. Lots of sculptures outside. No cameras but can take photos with mobile phones. Deposit cameras at entrance. Absolutely stunning collection of Indian art. Allow a whole day if you are really an art enthusiast.

Name: Barbara P
Title: Interesting collections, the New Wing could do with a refresh...
Review: Note - the museum opens at 11am until further notice (not 9am, as advertised)Some very interesting pieces in the permanent collection - one of the security guards was very helpful in showing off his favorite pictures, and rightly so!The new wing (permanent exhibition) feels as if it could do with a refresh (better lighting etc), but has gorgeous pieces - the Annexe building collection feels  crammed in places despite the rooms being so spacious, and that collection feels a little more random/not as consistent in terms of quality.Other exhibitions were really lovely.

Name: Shabnam Akram
Title: I love the way it has grown to bring you great new art
Review: Well worth the trip. With a collection of modern Indian art to rival the best and ongoing special exhibitions, its a good place to a get a sense of modern Indian Art.

Name: callumx
Title: A large collection of contemporary art from the 19th Century onwards
Review: The National Gallery of Modern Art hosts a large collection of art (mainly paintings with a few sculptures). The main building is used to host rotating exhibitions, and the modern annex buildings display the gallery's extensive permanent collection. The gallery is spacious, pleasantly air conditioned, and has a very relaxed atmosphere. A wander around the gallery shows how painting styles in India have developed, initially drawing on European influences, but then developing unique Indian flavours. I happily spent a couple of hours soaking up the culture. As ever with modern art, some paintings are exquisite and others banal. There is something here to please everybody.

Name: Mike
Title: 2nd great visit
Review: This is definitely worth a couple of hours when you are in Delhi. A great collection of art from artists not see in the west. Absolutely great. 500rs to enter and well worth it. There is usually a visiting exhibition.

Name: Mervin_3
Title: Modern art at its best
Review: If you like Modern art you must visit this place, it has all sorts of stuff in there and really good for someone who appreciates art. It also covers a decent amount of area and looks nice. Worth a visit.

Name: RC03
Title: Lovely afternoon, Amrita Shergil’s work is stunning
Review: When the temperature rises, an afternoon inside this gallery, with its mix of artists, eras, and insights is pure, cool relief and delight!  It may not be your first choice of activities, but that’s only because the capital region has so much to offer.  Still, the National Gallery should be very high on your list of ‘must sees’ regardless of the outside temperatures.

Name: Daf0dil
Title: Inspiring Art Gallery
Review: For Art lovers, this place is a must visit. The Creative structures on the outside garden area is thought provoking. you can see a lot of art school students practicing their sketching skills inspired by some of the complex sketches for common man's eye. If you don't like to shop in busy malls , then this place is a good stop for you.

Name: Karen M
Title: Stunning but don't drink the chai!
Review: The gallery is a quiet sanvtuary/ oasis with a broad ranging, stunning collection of Modern Art.  The cafe however is a wasted opportunity.  It is a big cavernous space with little furniture and only offers chai and packets of biscuits. It was grubby. I cannot prove it but am certain that the vomiting and diahrrea I started later that day came from thst cup of chai. I was severely ill. Be warned! 3 stars only because of the chai, otherwise 5.

Name: kzybvb
Title: Very interesting gallery, worth a visit if you like art.
Review: My wife and I found this museum very interesting and definitely worth a visit if you like modern art especially paintings. All the art was of very high quality and very interesting. It is a large museum with multiple levels, so plan a couple hours to enjoy it.

Name: dalhi_girl
Title: Nice day out learning about art
Review: The gallery has an impressive collection of paintings. It starts from the start of the modern period in the 19th century all the way to present day. They have paintings from great stalwarts of art like Amrita Shergill, Nandalal bose, Jamini Roy and contemporary artists... I am sure many of the paintings would cost a lot in the art market. It's a great place for an art outsider to get acquainted with modern art. They have lockers for your things, an RO for drinking water, and the loos were in very good condition as per museum standards. A good place for a day out. It's good for a day out.

Name: Jyan n
Title: An interesting place for sure
Review: The Nation Gallery of Modern Art in New Delhi provides quite a nice array of artwork; paintings, photographs and sculptures.There are four floors of modern art in various art media in large formats as wells miniatures.It is easily accessible to wheel chairs and walkers.  Its surroundings provides a peaceful grassy area to have a lunch.

Name: Zoltán W
Title: Magnificent environment
Review: The building, the garden, the galleries, the staff are exceptional. Especially the Amrita Sher-Gill collection. Spend there at least a day.

Name: monuk572
Title: Delhi One Day Tour visit
Review: Excellent Service provide by monu votre chauffeue en lnde for one day delhi tour visit. excellent service, clean car etc.

Name: jackieallan2017
Title: Indian artists
Review: Beautiful museum on several levels displaying modern Indian artists and sulpturers. Interesting pictures depicting Gandi's life and important battles.

Name: Prachi J
Title: Wonderful Experience! Guided tour is a must take.
Review: They have amazing collection of paintings arranged in the order of period they were painted in. It shows the evolution of art from imaginary miniatures to abstract art form. There is a guided tour at 11 AM,1:30 PM and 4 PM.Its free of cost and a must take. I am from not from art background and he really helped me understand the painting,what to see in it and the evolution of art in India. Museum is huge will take good 3 hours to make a fair justice to the place.

Name: vikrant s
Title: Prefect destination for art lover
Review: This place is hub for one who loves art and have soft Cornor for Indian paintings.One need at least  min 3 hours to see entire gallery which is spread in 4 floors in 2 different  wings, at first it look like nothing special but as you start seeing you get your eyes mezermising with painting. All most all of renoved artist you will find here and they and this place is blessed with rare art collection too.7-10 mins of walk for khan market metro station and very close to India gate too.For Indian 20 rs is fee and please note that it's written photography is not allowed, though when I enquired they said that I can click pictures but no selfie and no to flash.You may please clarify to avoid such event as security is really tight here, every floor has 2 gaurds along with 1 gentleman in formal uniform to take care.Before visiting I read TripAdvisor review for AC, well it's quite good I don't find any such problem and you can't carry bags etc, so lockers is there for free where you can put your stuff.There is also art section which has printed forms of painting like posters, coasters pads etc which you can buy.You may also go to Jaipur house which has aesthetic design and projection of nature on wall with sound effects.It's worth going there... specially in this summers as it's fun to be here.I would recommend going by 230 so you can spend good amount of time there as it's remain open till 6 or 630 and then walk for ice cream to India gate!Simple!Hit like if you feel my review worth information.

Name: Ben T
Title: National Gallery provides respite from the heat - for the eyes
Review: The National Gallery Of Modern Art shows a collection over several floors as well as the adjacent Jaipur House.The collection is predominantly painting; I was most taken by some of the watercolour and tempura works as well as photographs taken during the Ghandi era.Admission is 20 RS for locals and 500 RS for foreign nationals. You will be requested to check in your bag and sign for a locker.Please note current opening hours are from 11am. Cafeteria sells snack food only.

Name: Kumar S
Title: National Gallery of Modern Art
Review: National Gallery of Modern Art is an must visit place for an art lover. Older as well as modern art can be found in abundance. Air conditioning can be an issue for few. Nearest metro station is Khan Market.

Name: Praveen
Title: Beautiful modern and traditional art Paintings
Review: If you are a art lover then must visit place for you. The art gallery is good. photography is not allowed. Beautiful place. All type of modern and old art paintings showed here. Very peaceful and beautiful environment. very well maintained and neat and clean. It is one of the finest art gallery of India.

Name: gentbrugg
Title: New pages
Review: For me it is one of the mandatory places to visit in Delhi. In India there is only one similar Museum - in Mumbai, having the status of branch of the Delhi one. However, it seems to open soon in Bangalore next branch, but not yet.  If all else – by the way, in principle, almost all surrounding neighborhood - looks already written and turned page in the history and culture of India, but here in this building, built as the residence of the Raja of Jaipur, are being written the absolutely new pages. I mean contemporary art exhibitions for which the museum among other things is designed. Although there are permanent exhibitions – as improvised (like sculptures in front of the entrance) and thematically verified. There is also a miniature painting, as elsewhere in India, though still with an emphasis on Mysore, Calcutta and Tanjoor art school, but far more important from my point of view is, for example, the Department of "Academic realism", presenting Indian art from the unexpected for the Europeans side. Or the exhibits that give an idea about the school of  "Bengal Renaissance". Separate exposition is dedicated to the works of European artists, then to the works of Rabindranath Tagore and members of his family. And this is only a small part among the nearly twenty thousand units of storage.

Name: Daniel S
Title: Great older paintings from local artists
Review: I am a fan of the older paintings. The drawings and prints fascinate me. This is a must see. I would get a driver to drive you there. The main issue there is no water is permitted in the facility. This makes the visit a short one for foreign visitors that need bottled water. One cannot even go to the door and get your own water and drink. This needs to be fixed. There is a cafe outside of the gallery. Too bad one cannot enjoy this place a longer time.

Name: Mike
Title: Wonderful
Review: I was amazed at the collection of modern art from all over the world. No restaurant but certainly worth a visit. When i was there i was almost alone on some of the floors.

Name: Kanika_Das
Title: Too Hot Here
Review: I had not liked this because this place is to hot even no eatables or washroom available here I'll never visit here I visited here with my Canadian friend he said I don't want to see these type of places and monuments at all , it was so shameful for me too ,

Name: Mohan126
Title: Indian Paintings from 1850 onward
Review: Plan your visit to be at NGMA by 11.00 AM, or 1.30 P.M. or 3.30 PM to walk through the collection of painting housed on 5 floors with a guide. We recently had an informative tour of the NGMA with a knowledgeable guide.The NGMA houses from early miniature paintings on palm leaf  to the most modern works of art by contemporary artists. How the art movement has progressed with time, availability of paints,  large size canvases, and techniques of reproduction of multiple copies of limited additions.One can buy reprints, books, mugs and coasters of many artists from the art shop.NGMA also hold special exhibitions from time to time. We were told that NGMA is trying to bring in some good   Resturent on Campus. Present canteen is not worth a visit.

Name: jsrvstv7
Title: Must visit for Art enthusiast!
Review: This museum is located near India Gate. The entry fee is ₹20 per adult.No cameras/ mobile cameras are allowed. You are strictly prohibited not to touch the paintings.The paintings are exhibited in a huge three storey area in two buildings.You will love the paintings and three hours would be less for a art enthusiast.You may find it difficult to cover the full museum in one day if you look at each and every painting with full attention ( you will not be able to resist not looking at them though).Museum's timings are 10 am to 5 pm , Tuesday to Sunday. It has a cafeteria which serves delicious samosas ( size is small though), bread pakoras, alloo bondas and other package niching stuff.

Name: anacriiss96
Title: Incredible
Review: Loved the exhibitions and the art pieces were magnificent! Any art lover must visit this museum whilst in New Delhi, its a complete delight

Name: Amy D
Title: Art lovers must visit
Review: Mordern art gallery extremely beautiful place , highly maintained , spread in vast area . The art gallery is pretty good. one can see  paintings from the early 18th century  till today. It also has a hall for sculptures.huge art collection . this is my second visit .mobile phones , photography r not allowed . The ideas and style of painting is mindblowing, , they have collection of art of famous artist of indian  aw well international .Ticket is around 20 bucks for indian & 500 for foreigner . little shp inside the gallery where one buy art books , prints of painting of their favourite artist .

Name: Gugan_Ilango
Title: decent place to spend to avoid the heat
Review: National Gallery of Modern Art located at Jaipur House, is a decent place to spend the afternoon to avoid the heat. not that great. but can visit once

Name: Harsh P
Title: Only for art lovers
Review: It was disappointing to take my friend here who cannot understand the logic behind art. Throughout the visit, he kept interpreting the presentations in a funny and absurd way. I would've rather visited alone to check out the creations . Some with engineering involved and others with logic and imagination like paintings and sculptures

Name: Ab_79_del
Title: Nice weekend place in Delhi
Review: Good place for visitors. Nice place to see India's heritage. Must visit for people travelling from outside Delhi

Name: RC03
Title: Great Gem!
Review: Visited today -- A very nice collection of contemporary Indian Art from, mainly, the early 19th to early 21st centuries.  Divided onto four floors plus two additional galleries, the collection is both manageable and accessible.  The knowledgeable staff really helps you appreciate the evolution of two and three dimensional art in India.  I fell in love with Amrita Sher-Gil -- what an amazing array of work she produced in her short life; Jamini Roy's work was a delight, and their small but amazing collection of art and sculpture by BC Sanyal, shows why he was the Baba of Indian Art.  Except for an especially well behaved school group, I had this cool, well organized gallery virtually to myself for my 3-hr visit.  Definitely worth a visit.

Name: anithaaravamuthan
Title: Interesting place!!!
Review: Historical place with lots of pictures and the modern art. Its a attractive place. Lots of collection. For Students and kids, the place will be useful.

Name: phebert
Title: An interesting collection
Review: Definitely worth a visit.  More representational art than one normally finds in a modern art gallery.  Particularly enjoyed works by Thomas Deniell, Antonio Trinidade and Amrita Sher-Gil.

Name: Indiane_touristVisa
Title: Very attractive place for Art loving people!
Review: Moder Art is unique method of sharing expression on various topics or issues without speaking anything.

Name: Neelaksh P
Title: Surprise Surprise
Review: Its a must visit place in Delhi .Invariably, people not keep  adequate time required by this place.Students in 8/9 standard can easily connect with their history lessons.

Name: Nikhil P
Title: Collection of modern art
Review: Located near India gate, this is a treasure cove for the art lovers who will rejoice the vast collection of paintings, artefacts being kept at the museum. Only regret is that photography is not allowed at the museum . There are no entry charges for entry to the museum.

Name: Filmwalah
Title: One Stop Collection of Modern Art in India
Review: A must visit for travellers visting Delhi. The Museum has an impressive collection of contemporary Indian artists , including a very substantian body of work by the Indo-Hungarian artist Amrita Sher Gil. It is also the home for international artists whose works are showcased here on a regular basis.

Name: Romaroma
Title: Don't go Sunday, the cafe is closed
Review: There was a lot of art here. The art done by Western artists was easier for me to understand, but it was good to try to get a feel for the different periods of Indian art.

Name: tripsmaker
Title: Experiencing the Indian School
Review: It is a premier art gallery under Ministry of culture, Government of India located in Jaipur house on Janpath, New Delhi. It showcase many paintings of eminent artist of Indian school of art, such as Thomas Daniel, Raja Ravi Verma, Abanindranath Tagore, Rabindranath Tagore, Gaganendranath Tagore, Nandalal Base, Jamini Roy. It's a great place for art lovers and a place of tourist interest in Delhi.

Name: Jacoba S
Title: An interesting experience
Review: The museum is very large and has very weird and wonderful things in it. The best bits are by no means very modern. It also houses miniatures of the 10th century. The 3rd and 4th floors of the New building have really very nice paintings and are well worth seeing although also date from late 19th century to the mid 19 hundreds. But these works are the best. Floor 3a and 4a House very large and indeed modern works that one cannot make head or tail of. I spent a lovely afternoon there away from the Delhi din and traffic noise. But once seen I do not have to go back again.

Name: Parth T
Title: Refreshing enriching experience
Review: A great place to feel inspired and bring out the inner creativity. To properly explore all the exhibit would take a full day, but is worth the effort.Paintings by Thomas Daniell are worth special mention.

Name: Santosh D
Title: Visit to National Gallery of Art
Review: The National Gallery of Modern Art  at jaipur house was established in  1954 by the Indian government. Its collection of more than 14,000 works includes works by artists such as Thomas Daniell, Raja Ravi Verma, Abanindranath Tagore, Rabindranath Tagore, Gaganendranath Tagore, Nandalal Bose, Jamini Roy, Amrita Sher-Gil as well as foreign artists, apart from sculptures by various artists. The butterfly-shaped building with a central auditorium and built in 1936, and designed by Sir Arthur Bloomfield, after the construction of Lutyens' Delhi. In fact in 2009, a new building of the National Gallery of Modern Art was inaugurated adding almost six times the space to the existing gallery, plus it has a new auditorium, a preview theatre, conservation laboratory, library and academic section as well as a cafeteria and museum shop. One should visit the place at least once.

Name: S Srinivasa Rao
Title: Interesting for people associated with Modern Art
Review: National Art Gallery of Modern Art is a place which is a must see for Modern Art lovers. People who love and have a liking for Modern Art will certainly fall in love with this place.
